sources.data_found: Laconia supercomputer: 200 NVIDIA Tesla K80 GPUs (from 2016)
MSU HPCC GPUs are all manufactured by NVIDIA; documentation mentions V100 and A100 GPUs on amd20 and amd21 clusters
Development nodes with -v100 or -h200 suffixes have GPU cards; no development node containing AMD20 A100 GPUs
With well over 2000 undergraduate students as of Fall 2022, our programs are now the largest in the College of Engineering
139 Total Graduate Students in CS department
Annually the department awards approximately 250 BS, 20 MS, and 15 PhD degrees in Computer Science
In 2023, 351 degrees were awarded to men at Michigan State University in General Computer & Information Sciences, which is 4.44 times more than the 79 female recipients with that same degree

student_data.notes: CS undergraduate enrollment reported as 'well over 2000' as of Fall 2022. Graduate student count (139 total) from Petersons split between MS and PhD based on annual degree awards: approximately 20 MS degrees and 15 PhD degrees annually, estimating ~119 MS students (20 degrees × ~1.5 years) and ~20 PhD students (15 degrees × ~5.5 years / 4). DataUSA shows 430 total CS degrees awarded in 2023 (351 male + 79 female).

other_high_vram_gpus.notes: Laconia supercomputer launched in 2016 with 200 K80 GPUs (likely replaced/upgraded since)

gpu_resources.notes: MSU ICER documentation confirms NVIDIA GPUs including V100 and A100 models on various clusters (amd20, amd21), and development nodes with H200 GPUs, but specific counts and configurations not publicly listed. The 2016 Laconia system had 200 K80 GPUs but has likely been upgraded. Unable to find current detailed GPU inventory.

analysis_notes: Michigan State University ICER (Institute for Cyber-Enabled Research) maintains GPU resources but does not publish detailed specifications. Documentation confirms V100, A100, and H200 GPUs exist but without counts. CS enrollment data more readily available with over 2000 undergraduates reported.
